com.sri.ai.grinder.core.constraint

Class AbstractSingleVariableConstraint

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sri.ai.grinder.core.AbstractExpression
      • com.sri.ai.expresso.helper.AbstractExpressionWrapper
        • com.sri.ai.grinder.core.constraint.AbstractConstraint
          • com.sri.ai.grinder.core.constraint.AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Expression, Constraint, SingleVariableConstraint, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithDependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithIndependentNormalizedAtoms, SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms

    @Beta
public abstract class AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
extends AbstractConstraint
implements SingleVariableConstraint
    An abstract Expression with efficient internal representation for a conjunction in a given theory. It does the basic work of weeding out redundant literals and detecting syntactic contradictions (based simply on atom identity). Furthermore, it can use implication between literals of different atoms, defined by extensions knowledgeable of specific theories in order to detect further redundancies and inconsistencies, thus decreasing the effort to define theory solvers.
    Author:
    braz
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • makeSimplificationWithoutExternalLiterals

        public AbstractSingleVariableConstraint makeSimplificationWithoutExternalLiterals()
        Description copied from interface: SingleVariableConstraint
        Creates a simplification of this constraint that is equal to it but for the absence of external literals. However, it is important to notice that, because the result is considered a simplification, it can only be used in contexts in which the original constraint (and therefore the external literals) hold, because it may still assume them to hold. While this may at first seem like an unnecessary restriction, it allows implementations to count on the external literal information to keep whatever internal bookkeeping that depends on the original constraint, avoiding the need to repeated computation.

        For example, equality constraints keep track of how many disequalities against uniquely named constants have been observed on the constraint's variable so far (even the disequalities that have been discarded since then). Copying this information to the new constraint is only justified if we know it is going to be used as a simplification of the original constraint, since it may not follow from the normalized atoms and external literals alone.

        Specified by:
        makeSimplificationWithoutExternalLiterals in interface SingleVariableConstraint
        Returns:

      • getExternalLiterals

        public java.util.List<Expression> getExternalLiterals()
        Description copied from interface: SingleVariableConstraint
        A single-variable constraint has the ability to temporarily hold literals not on its variable. This returns such literals. This works as a buffer for literals propagated (deduced) at the point in which the constraint is formed (by conjunction with another), so that they don't need to be deduced every time we need to check if there are literals to be propagated.
        Specified by:
        getExternalLiterals in interface SingleVariableConstraint
        Returns:

      • fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral

        public abstract Expression fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral(Expression normalizedAtom)
        Returns the literal corresponding to the negation of the given normalized atom. Typically this will just return the application of NOT to the atom, but some languages may have more conventional (and more pleasing to read) ways of representing these negations (for example, not(X = a) -> X != a).
        Parameters:
        normalizedAtom -
        Returns:

      • destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom

        public abstract AbstractSingleVariableConstraint destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom(boolean sign,
                                                                                                         Expression atom,
                                                                                                         Context context)
        Extending classes define this method to perform whatever checks are needed after a new atom has been inserted, returning null in case of a detected contradiction or this object, or a simplified version of it, otherwise.

        In general, this will contain whatever theory-specific checks and simplifications that go beyond simple contradiction between normalized atoms.

        One example of this method being useful is in equality theory with finite domains. If a variable is constrained to be disequal to n distinct values and its type size is equal or less than n, we know the constraint is unsatisfiable. Because AbstractSingleVariableConstraint knows nothing about equalities, it will not detect that. An extension defining equality constraints can define this method to perform such check.

        Parameters:
        sign -
        atom -
        context -
        Returns:

      • conjoinWithLiteral

        public SingleVariableConstraint conjoinWithLiteral(Expression formula,
                                                   Context context)
        Description copied from interface: Constraint
        Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given literal, or null if they are contradictory.

        At this point, the formula should be either a literal, or a Constraint.

        Specified by:
        conjoinWithLiteral in interface Constraint
        Parameters:
        formula - the literal to be conjoined.
        context - the context
        Returns:
        the application result or null if contradiction.

        public AbstractSingleVariableConstraint makeContradiction()
        Description copied from interface: Constraint
